results.title: Le Crime de Monsieur Lange = Crime of Monsieur Lange
results.creator_credit: Andre Halley des Fontaines and Jean Renoir
results.brief_description:
Lange is an author of wild west novels. When the owner of the company that publishes Lange’s works absconds with the company funds, Lange rallies the employees together to create their own publishing house. The publisher returns, disguised as a priest, and demands a share of the profits. Lange responds by killing him. The grateful employees help Lange to escape prosecution, allowing him to leave the country with his lovely fiancee. It is a joyous film, just as the Popular Front was a joyous movement, happy in the belief that living and working conditions could be changed for the better and fascism resisted at home and abroad. Exploitation (including sexual exploitation) are represented as the product of authoritarian capitalism, here represented by the publisher. Lange’s crime is what the poet W. H. Auden deemed a ‘necessary murder’. It is committed to prevent the destruction of the new world that has been built by a mini ‘Popular Front’ of progressive capitalists and workers by hand and by brain. When the film was re-released in the 1960’s, more attention was paid to its formal qualities (the staging of action in depth, an apparent 360 degree pan spotted by the great French critic Andre Bazin) than its political content.

Credits: Producer, Andre Halley des Fontaines ; director, Jean Renoir ; writers, Jean Renoir, Jacques Prevert ; photography, Jean Bachelet ; music, Jean Wiener, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Jean Castanyer ; editor, Marguerite Houlle-Renoir.
Cast: Rene Lefevre, Jules Berry, Fiorelle, Nadia Sibirskaia, Henri Guisol, Sylvia Bataille, Maurice Baquet, Jean Daste, Marcel Levesque, Marcel Duhamel.

results.title: Le Crime de la Mule Noire = the Crime at the Black Mule Inn
results.brief_description:
Following his escape from the Bicetre prison, Vidocq arrives in a small village where a crime has just been committed. Vidocq is mistaken for Inspector Flambard and decides to test his police skills by investigating what really happened at the Black Mule Inn.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Claude Loursais ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Bruno Balp, Jacqueline Danno.

results.title: Le Corbeau = the Raven
results.brief_description:
A small French village is plagued by a poison pen writer, whose principal target is the town doctor. The vitriolic letters wreak so much havoc that soon neighbour turns upon neighbour. Eventually, the doctor himself is suspected of writing the letters, cloaking himself in the respectability of his office. When the psychiatrist starts receiving letters as well, he decides to investigate. Concluding that his own wife is the culprit, he has her committed. But soon after, more letters arrive … ‘Le Corbeau’ is a realistic portrait of Occupied France and its obsession for petty bickering and vengeful denunciation. Produced by the German production company ‘Continental Films’ the film was condemned as unpatriotic after the Liberation, and director Henri-Georges Clouzot was banned from filmmaking until 1947. Le Corbeau’ was remade in Hollywood by Otto Preminger as ‘The 13th Letter’ (1951).

Credits: Producer: Rene Montis ; director: Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writers, Henri-Georges Clouzot, Louis Chavance ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Tony Aubin ; sound, William-Robert Sivel.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Micheline Francey, Ginette Leclerc, Roger Blin, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Pierre Bertin, Pierre Larquey, Jean Brochard, Helene Manson, Noel Roquevert, Louis Seigner, Sylvie.

results.title: Le Ciel Est Bleu = the Sky Is Blue
results.brief_description:
A former war correspondant is given a new assignement as a sports journalist and sent to Dublin to cover a rugby match. While on assignment he meets a former American girlfiend and rekindles their affair.

Credits: Director, Serge Leroy ; writers, Serge Leroy, Myriam Lempereur ; photography, Jean-Jacques Rochut ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Frederic de Pasquale, Alexandra Stewart, Harry Brogan, Brian McGrath, Larbi Essakali, Liam O’Callaghan, Grace O’Shaughnessy.

results.title: Le Choix des Armes
results.brief_description: The high walls of a prison. Two running shadows in the night, a parked Volvo car whose engine is running. Suddenly, the shrieking sound of an alarm hooter. Both men get hastily inside the car which starts immediately. A well directed drama about a retired gangster (Yves Montand) forced into an antagonistic relationship with a young punk. (Gerard Depardieu).

results.title: Le Chevalier de Pardaillan
results.creator_credit: Andre Legrand, Andre Haguet and Bernard Borderie
results.brief_description:
In 1588, the Duke de Guise and princess Fausta are vying for the crown. Violetta, a young gypsy who has caught the duke’s eyes, is the object of a merciless competition between would-be lovers. When the duke discovers Violetta is of noble origins, he has her kidnapped in order to help in his attempt to overthrow the king. Pardaillan must then intervene to save the king and the damsel in distress.

Credits: Producers, Andre Legrand, Andre Haguet ; director, Bernard Borderie ; writers, Henri Haguet, Bernard Borderie ; photography, Henri Persin ; music, Paul Misraki ; costumes, Rosine Delamare.
Cast: Gerard Barray, Jean Topart, Gianna-Maria Canale, Michele Grellier, Guy Delorme.

results.title: Le Chevalier de Maison Rouge = the Cavalier Maison Rouge
results.brief_description:
Paris, 1793. Maurice Lindey, a young and fervent revolutionary rescues a mysterious woman from the clutches of the citizen’s army. That same night, Maison Rouge makes an attempts to have the Queen and the royal family escape from the Prison du Temple and a handsome reward is offered for his capture. Lindey follows the musterious woman, only to learn that her name is Genvieve Dixmer and that she is married to the owner of a tannery. Maurice is ivited to the house and recived as a firend. He is far too in love to realise that the house is full of conspirators. He even goes as far as introducing Genevieve to the Queen. When she is caught with a message for the Queen, again, Maurice covers for Genevieve and falls under the suspicion of his revolutionary friends.

Credits: Producer, Robert Paiilardon ; director, Claude Barma ; writers, Jacques Armand, Claude Barma ; photography, Jacques Lemare ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Annie Ducaux, Jean Desailly, Francois Chaumette, Julien Berthau, Dominique Paturel, Anne Doat, Michel Leroyer.

results.title: Le Cheval D'orgueil = the Horse of Pride
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Claude Chabrol
results.brief_description:
Between 1908 and 1918, Pierre-Jakez Helias spent his childhood in Bigouden country (French Brittany). The First World War brings about many changes in the traditional life of a village where pride is more abundant than riches. The central theme of the film is the perpetuation of Brittany’s culture (and language) via oral, rather than written tradition.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writer, Daniel Boulanger ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Pierre Jansen ; art direction, Hilton McConnico.
Cast: Jacques Dufilho, Bernadette Le Sache, Francois Cluzet, Dominique Lavanant, Michel Blanc, Paul Le Person, Michel Robin, Georges Wilson [narration only].

results.title: Le Chaud Lapin = the Hot Rabbit
results.brief_description:
William is a relentless womaniser who has to leave his many conquests behind to go and spend the summer vacation in a country house with relatives of one of his friends. Stranded in the isolated rural cottage, he attempts to bed every female member of the clan. Unsuccessful and extremely frustrated, he is determined to have some fun on his vacation and abandons the whole group in pursuit of a trio of hippyish females who flirted with him earlier.

Credits: Director, Pascal Thomas ; writers, Jacques Lourcelles, Pascal Thomas, Hubert Watrinet ; photography, Colin Mounier ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Bernard Menez, Daniel Ceccaldi, Brigitte Gruel.
